div1.head: Interview of Jefferson Randolph Kean, by Philip Showalter Hench, January 6, 1944
div1.opener:
INTERVIEW by P S Hench WITH GENERAL J. R. KEAN, U.S. Army, RET.
WASHINGTON, D.C.
January 6, 1944.

item.p:
QUESTION #1 Adolph Springer was a soldier whose name I found in
the Walter Reed notebook owned by the New York Academy of Medicine.
He is a man who was bitten by a pungens mosquito. His name does
not appear in any of the official documents. Do you know who he
was and why he did not get on the roll of honor?

ANSWER: Springer was a member of the Detachment Hospital Corps
at Camp Columbia and his name appears as No. 35 on the nominal list
of that Detachment made by General Truby to go with the group photo-
graph of it. I am sure that you have a copy of it (marked photo. 14).
When General Ireland and I helped make out the qualifications for the
roll of honor, we decided not to include any one who did not actually
get experimental yellow fever, with the exception of those who took
the fomites experiment. Therefore Springer would not have qualified.
I think he was probably a Hospital Corps man. Look at the picture
and Truby's identification list.

QUESTION #2: Who was Sergeant Neate? Answer: He was Reed's labor-
atory assistant brought down from Washington by him-

ANSWER: Reed decided to try the pungens on a few patients. He
knew that the pungens mosquito was common in places where there was
never any yellow fever and did not think that it had any connection
with it, but he wanted to try and see, and so he gave Sergeant Neate,
who was an excellent laboratory assistant and very faithful soldier,
the benefit of being on the list of volunteers in order that he might
get the money. This was, of course, before there was any definite
- 1 -
- 2 -
determination as to who should get on the roll of honor and who
should not. This was arrived at many years later (about 1929)
in my consultation with the Surgeon General.

QUESTION #3 Why then does not Neat's name appear in any of Reed's
papers, and why is not his experiment mentioned in any of Reed's
papers, and why didn't he get the money - or did he?

ANSWER: He did - $100.00. Reed and I decided how to expend
the Cuban Yellow Fever Fund, and Neate was bitten by a pungens mos-
quito. This was not done at Camp Lazear, but was done at the yellow
fever ward at Columbia Barracks for the following reason: The pun-
gens is a nervous mosquito which could not be made to bite an indi-
vidual when in the test tube, so they were placed inside of a mos-
quito net of a patient sick with yellow fever to be inoculated.
The technique of applying this mosquito was different from the yellow
fever mosquito. Reed would release several pungens under the mos-
quito netting of a yellow fever patient in the first few days. He
would leave them there over night, catching them in test tubes against
the mosquito netting, and put the mosquitoes back in their jars for
a variable number of days, and then release them under the mosquito
net of those apparently few non-immunes on whom Reed tried this ex-
periment. Neate is the only one I actually know who received this
experiment, but as you say Springer must have also received this
experiment. Apparently Reed omitted from his papers reference to
these pungens experiments because they were negative and not im-
portant. Whether Springer got $100.00 for volunteering, I do not
remember. He certainly did if Reed recommended him for it.

QUESTION #4: This Spring when I visited Mrs. Lazear I told her that
it was the generally accepted story that Dr. Lazear kept from her the
knowledge of his work in order that if anything happened to him his
insurance would not be forfeited. Mrs. Lazear was surprised at this,
and it was very difficult for her to believe this version as she had
no recollection that Dr. Lazear left any insurance. It was her idea
that Dr. Lazear kept the matter secret simply in order not to worry
her. What is your reaction to the “insurance story”?

ANSWER: If she did not get any insurance I would accept the
explanation that there was none. There was no government insurance
in those days like there is today. It was only assumed as a guess
that Lazear had this reason for not putting his own experiment on
record.

QUESTION #5: In my interview of May 8, 1941 in Question #28, I
asked you what kind of a stove they probably had in Building #1.
You thought it was probably not an army stove, but suggested it might
have been a coal oil stove. Some one has said that a coal oil stove
would not have a stove pipe. Do you have anything further to say
on that? What kind of a stove would be appropriate to put in
Building #1 when we reconstruct it? Moran does not remember seeing
the stove, but thinks it might have been a big bellied iron with an
isinglass window and a little flat top on which to put a pan of
increase B
water to relieve humidity.

ANSWER: I really do not know. I thought it might have been
a Franklin stove, but I never saw a Franklin stove in Cuba. Why not
- 3 -
- 4 -
ask the Cubans what kind of a stove might have been purchased there
at that time? I still think it might have been a coal oil stove,
as this oil makes no smoke, but it might have had a stove pipe never-
theless to carry off the products of combustion. Probably army wood over
B.

QUESTION #6: In Reed's letter to General Sternberg July 24, 1900
Reed speaks about “the stupid blunder of Godfrey and his assistants”.
Who were Godfrey's assistants? I thought Cooke was the only one.
See Hench called

ANSWER: The number of regular medical officers was exceedingly
short in Cuba and most of the medical service was done by Contract
Surgeons. Godfrey was the only regular surgeon at Pinar del Rio.
General Truby states that one of them might have been A.A. Surgeon
Pilsnell (I think it should be spelled Presnall). There was also
no one knows it was Y. F
one named Alden. Cooke was the one in charge of the yellow fever
ward. When I returned to Marianao on August 13, 1900 from sick
leave in the United States, I found that Captain Stark, who had been
post surgeon, had investigated the matter and had not recommended any
He did not in his letters!
punishment for negligence. Stark's excusing Cooke made the likli-
hood of court martial of Cooke and Godfrey impossible. I went up
to Pinar del Rio to decide about the disposition of infected property.
I recommended to the Surgeon General that Dr. Cooke's contract be
annulled. Although he was in charge of the ward, he had not kept
records of the urine, temperature and pulse according to the circu-
lars of instructions - at least he had not done enough to make a
diagnosis. Cooke felt very badly about it and came down to Marianao
and offered himself to Reed as an experimental case. He made no de-
fense to me. Major Reed came to me and asked if I would object to
- 4 -
- 5 -
his taking Cooke on as a volunteer for the yellow fever tests. I was
glad to say that I would not object. Thereafter I wrote, or cabled,
the Surgeon General withdrawing my previous recommendation to void
Cooke's contract.

QUESTION #7: Why were you so angry at Cooke? Did you not realize
that he had only been in the Army, and had only been in Cuba a very
short time - I believe in Cuba only a couple of weeks? He has told
me that he knew nothing of yellow fever, had never seen a case, and
that Captain Godfrey, his superior, had not corrected his mistakes.
He considered his mistake quite explainable and never had any feeling
of guilt although he was, of course chagrined.

ANSWER: I did not know that Cooke had been such a short time in
Cuba and supposed that he knew the standing instructions about exami-
nation of all fever cases. Now it seems to me distinctly to his
credit that he did not try to avoid my censure. He did not try to ex-
cuse his delinquency; he has always been a very modest and manly gentle-
man.

QUESTION #8: What was your reaction to Godfrey who was even more re-
sponsible and whose ignorance is more blameable?

ANSWER: I think he was entirely inexcusable, but as he had been
examined and reprimanded by Captain Stark (this was only a verbal
reprimand) I felt that nothing could be done in his case, but I knew
that he could never get a promotion in the Medical Department. I
always felt that he should have been court-martialed.

QUESTION #9: When you wired Mrs. Lazear that Dr. Lazear had died
- 5 -
- 6 -
your wire is very short, and simply says that he had died and gave the
hour of death. Mrs. Lazear did not even know he was sick. Looking
at the wire now, the telegram looks very brief and cold and almost
militarily cruel. Why was that sort of a wire sent?

ANSWER: Those were the days of strict economy. I should have
written, if I did not. I assumed that someone else had informed her
of his illness, because I had been away on an inspection trip during
his illness. Incidentally, when I had yellow fever Captain Stark
sent a cable to my family every day. I had to pay for these messages
at the rate of $2.00 or $3.00 a word, and I regretted that he had
issued so much information.

QUESTION #9: In your diary and elsewhere you have stated that on
October 12, 1900 you went with Reed to see General Wood, and so far as
you know this is the first time that Reed suggested using and paying
Spanish immigrants for experimental purposes as volunteers.

ANSWER: If Reed had before this discussed with General Wood the
use of Spanish volunteers, he never told me, and I do not believe that
he did. As regards American volunteers I think the question had
never been raised, and was a personal responsibility with Reed. The
American soldier had a right to volunteer, and the only responsibility
involved would be a violation of the quarantine regulations. In re-
porting the case of XY in his preliminary report he was anxious not to
reveal that XY was a soldier because it would have been a violation of
the quarantine orders. Reed had not used XY, but his assistants had,
and if Colonel Baldwin had wanted to he could have censured Reed severe-
- 6 -
- 7 -
ly for that experiment. I laughed and told Reed that unless he ad-
mitted that XY was a soldier he would have a hard time making it clear
that he had had no previous exposure. Reed admitted this and took
the chance. Later when a Captain of an Artillery Company made an of-
ficial complaint through channels to General Wood that one of his men
had been infected with yellow fever as an experiment, he was given to
understand that this was not a military matter. Nothing came about
the matter of XY as far as Reed and the Commanding Officer were con-
cerned. Probably nothing was heard of the facts in the case until
it was too late to take any action.

QUESTION #10: It is generally accepted that it was decided on August
1, 1900 to use human volunteers. Reed and Agramonte had returned
from Pinar del Rio, and on August 1 the four met at Camp Columbia on
the veranda of the Officers' Quarters and decided, or at least offi-
cially decided to use human volunteers. Most of the stories infer
that the matter was first considered then and was decided on that day,
but in Reed's letter to General Sternberg July 24, 1900 Reed definite-
ly mentions the probable necessity of experimentation on human beings.
Obviously, although it might have been finally decided on August 1 to
use volunteers, at least Reed had had that in mind for some time.

ANSWER: That is perfectly clear. However, whether Reed had dis-
cussed his ideas on human volunteers with the others, that I do not
know.

QUESTION #11: In Mrs. Reed's scrap book about her husband, I have found
a newspaper article dated April 11, 1905 (city and name of paper not
identified) with a photograph of the isolation buildings of the yellow
- 7 -
- 8 -
fever hospital at Columbia Barracks. Do these little buildings look
familiar to you; do you think this is where you were sick with yellow
fever?

ANSWER: I think that I was treated in one of these buildings,
but I am not now able to identify each one.

QUESTION #12: In looking at these old photographs, and also comparing
them with the 1902 map of Columbia Hospital, where do you think the
road was, and also the railroad?

ANSWER: I do not know, but it would appear since the back of one
faces the front of another that they were all probably facing the rail-
road tracks, that is northeast. As I remember it, there was a narrow
footbridge, which I remember very well, across the Marinao railroad
track, probably passing half way between the road and the rows of little
buildings, and I believe that the wagon road approached the little
buildings from the south and then may have gone down between the two
rows of little buildings, but your guess is as good as mine.

QUESTION #13: Supplementing your answer to question 16 as given in our
interview of May 8, 1941 about the presentation ceremony when a watch
was given to Kissinger and not to Moran, may I say the following:
When I saw Moran at Walter Reed Hospital in August, 1943, Moran stated
his impression was that when Kissinger was cited he received not only
a watch, but a purse. Moran thought that the hospital corps men had
made a collection and enough was left over ($115.00) from the price of
the watch to give him that much money extra. Moran was also under
the impression that General KennedyMaj Kean was not present at the ceremony,
- 8 -
- 9 -
and that Reed presented the watch. Do you have any further remarks
about this?

Sen Ted Kean wrote “There was no General Kennedy in
Cuba & no General at the ceremony. My recollection is that the only officers present were medical officers.” (Kean).

ANSWER: I believe that I was present at the ceremony, and I am
sure that Havard, and not Reed, presented the watch. He was given
no extra money at that time. The date of this ceremony you can find
approximately by looking up the letter of Carroll in which he told
his wife that he had bought the watch for Kissinger. It might be a
good idea to write to Kissinger, as the date of the ceremony might
be on the watch. The watch and chain cost about $115.00, and probably
in a week or ten days Kissinger came to me and asked if the watch cost
all of the $200.00, and when I said “No”, he asked if he could have the
balance. (Just off the record - you can see that Kissinger went back
on his original intention to volunteer without reward. Despite this,
all these years Kissinger has allowed everyone to believe he never ac-
cepted a reward. However, Moran stuck to his agreement and never ac-
cepted any reward until the Government rewarded him years later, and is,
therefore, in a separate class from Kissinger). It was because of
Moran's insistance that he be not rewarded, that it never occurred to
me to get him a watch or any other reward.

The watch ceremony was undoubtedly held on the parade ground of
the hospital, that is between the wards and the Bachelor Officers'
quarters, and there were probably present only the men on duty that
day - maybe twenty five or so.

QUESTION #14: Moran also feels a little hurt that when he was invited
to attend the ceremony, he simply stood by himself in the rear some-
where. General Truby explained this to me about this way: “There is
- 9 -
- 10 -
no place for a civilian in a military ceremony”. However, my re-
action is that since Moran had been in the army just a few weeks be-
fore and had done such a meritorious thing, he might have been invited
to stand in a special place. What is your reaction to this?

ANSWER: I believe that would have been a very proper thing to
do, but apparently no one thought of it.

(Comment by Dr. Hench: This recalls to me Moran's statement in
one of his early letters to me that through the years he has never
willingly sought any monetary reward, although he has been a perennial
candidate for any medal from leather to gold. Obviously Moran did
not want the money, but even at that date he would have been very
happy to receive a watch or any other non-monetary reward, and his not
getting a watch has hurt him all these years.)

QUESTION #15: Have they told you what Lambert told me that in the be-
ginning Lambert believes that Reed was afraid of yellow fever?

(Here Dr. Hench told Lambert's story about Reed using camphor in
the autopsy room and not approaching the body, and also how Lambert
interfered with Reed's putting a mosquito on one of Lambert's very
sick patients).
What is your reaction to this story?

ANSWER: I do not believe most of it. I am sure I would be afraid
of things, but it would not prevent me from doing my duty. Reed un-
doubtedly did not want to expose himself needlessly to yellow fever,
but I am sure he was ready to check the experiments, if and when it be-
came necessary, and would take any exposure which was justified.
- 10 -
- 11 -
I do not believe anything of the camphor story.

(OFF THE RECORD: (Dr. Hench) Here I told General Kean about
Lambert's supposed little episode when Major Kean asked to see the
thermometer. General Kean remembers nothing about this, and although
Lambert may have been his nurse, he does not remember for sure; al-
though Major Kean does (not) recall that he was very sick, nevertheless
he appears to remember very little about his yellow fever illness).

QUESTION #16: Have you any further recollection of your conversation
with Reed before he died? Can you amplify what you told me about
your last visit to Walter Reed the night of his death?

ANSWER: Very little. I took Blossom down to see her father.
We were living in the same apartment at 1603 - 19th St., N.W. (I
think we lived on the third floor, and the Reeds on the second floor on
the south side of the hall). We stayed about ten minutes at the hos-
pital. I saw that Reed was dying; he was perfectly conscious and re-
cognized both of us at once. Blossom was overcome and left the room
immediately. Reed knew he was dying and wanted to say goodbye to her.
I found Blossom completely overcome and unable to go back into the room;
therefore I made some excuse to Reed why she did not go back. I told
him I thought it was the odor of the room that made her sick, and he
said, “Well take her home, Kean”. We talked just a few minutes more,
and it was then I told him that I learned the Secretary of War had put
in his report just about to go out a recommendation that he should be
made a Colonel in the corps, and the Act also recommended Gorgas for
Lt. Colonel, but Reed replied, “I do not care for that now”. Then
he spoke about how little he was leaving his family, and was worried
- 11 -
- 12 -
over that. (See Dr. Kelley's book. I undoubtedly gave him that
story years ago when my memory was better.)

QUESTION #17: About three weeks ago when I visited Mrs. Reed at Blue
Ridge Summit, Blossom stated to me that her father would have become
the Surgeon General in a few months had he lived. I am sure that this
is wrong. I know that you suggested the nomination of Reed by writing
a letter to the Army and Navy Journal.

ANSWER: Obviously Blossom is wrong. O'Reilly was already
Surgeon General three months before Reed died.

QUESTION #18 Maybe Blossom thought her father might become Surgeon
General after O'Reilly served his term.

ANSWER: If so he would have had to wait eight years for O'Reilly
was Surgeon General for about that long.
QUESTION #19: How were the Spanish immigrants approached?

ANSWER: General Wood had been shocked at the Spanish immigrants
coming over and going into the city of Havana and becoming infected
with yellow fever, so he established a camp for Spanish immigrant
laborers on the heights of Cabana. That camp was under the quarantine
officer Menocal, and it was through Menocal that these men were pro-
cured. He apparently just went to them and told them of the offer of
employment and those who accepted were taken out to Camp Lazear, and
while they were being interned under initial quarantine they were
utilized to pick up stones. The owners of the large sugar plantations
- 12 -
- 13 -
would send over to Cabana for these Spaniards to work on the plantations.
They would take the train outside, thus avoiding Havana entirely, and
go out to the plantations where there was no danger of yellow fever.

A little later there was an article in La Discussion about the
cruel experiments being made on the Spaniards, but the Consul General,
a very nice man, told Reed not to worry, but to go ahead, but not to
take any under twenty four years. (The Spaniards do not become of
age until twenty four). The experiments were proposed to them, I
think, after they reached the camp.

(See my notes on General Kean's Diary, Nov. 23, 1900, also
Nov. 25).
QUESTION #20: Describe Lazear's funeral as much as you can.

ANSWER: There was a group of funerals of yellow fever cases in
the Autumn of 1900 that were superimposed in my mind so that I find
it difficult to get any separate picture of one as distinguished from
another. General Lee attended these funerals, and as he always liked
to go on horseback, he always turned out with his staff mounted although
the distance was not over about half a mile from headquarters, and a
quarter of a mile from the hospital. We rode in a group behind the
Red Cross ambulance carrying the coffin, and sat on our horses through
the very brief ceremony in the road on a very small plot - about 150
feet square. Such nurses not on duty, and a number of the hospital
corps men were present, but no general turnout of troops. There was
no turnout of troops on account of the nature of the disease. There
were probably forty or fifty. There was no band; there may have been
a drummer, and undoubtedly a bugler to blow taps. I do not believe
- 13 -
- 14 -
I do not believe there were drummers. Probably the corps men fell
in columns of twos behind the headquarters staff on horseback.

QUESTION #21: What is your reaction to Dr. Pinto's remark in his
letter to Truby, August 16, 1941: “We know that Agramonte was a dud”?

ANSWER: I think that Agramonte probably did all the work that
was expected and required of him. He was not relieved from other
duties, and his work on the Board was in combination with his other
work in his laboratory in Havana. That statement is too strong.

QUESTION #22: Do you think that Ames had yellow fever? (See your
letter to me of December 27, 1941 and June 26, 1942).

ANSWER: I do not believe he ever had yellow fever while in Cuba.
He claims to be immune, and it was for that reason that he was freely
admitted to Camp Lazear. See Major Reed's statement in the “Additional
Note” of the Yellow Fever Board in describing Camp Lazear.
also on Stark's d note

QUESTION #23: In Reed's letter to Mrs. Reed December 16, 1900 he
humoursly refers to when he might become Surgeon General. What is
the significance of this?
no
ANSWER: Just a jest.
QUESTION #24: Who was Madame Abreu?

ANSWER: She had a very beautiful home at Las Dilicias where she
entertained a great deal. She had a regular menagerie, among which
was a thoroughly trained chimpanzee which she called Chimpar. She
was a very public spirited woman, and I suppose offered Chimpar for
- 14 -
- 15 -
experiment. Agramonte told me that he got Chimpar and tried to give
him yellow fever, but he was perfectly immune. General Kean says, “I
do not think African monkeys can get yellow fever.”

QUESTION #25: What evidence do you know of that Reed was interested
in the mosquito before going to Havana? (I suspect strongly that he
was; however I find it very difficult to find any proof that he was.)

ANSWER: Dr. L. O. Howard, 45 Pondfield Road, West Bronxville,
N.Y., knows more about that than anyone else. I personally have no
knowledge on this point. He said that Reed and Carroll came to his
laboratory to study mosquitoes before they started to Cuba.

QUESTION #26: In Reed's letter to General Sternberg, July 24, 1900,
Reed criticises Godfrey unmercifully. I am surprised at the intensity
of this criticism. Godfrey had made a mistake, and a bad mistake, but
doctors can often make bad mistakes - even good doctors. Do you think
this criticism was too emphatic?

ANSWER: Not a bit. Every physician down there was constantly
sent circulars and instructions concerning yellow fever and the chief
diagnostic problem. After all Godfrey had eleven post-mortems and
should certainly have known he was dealing with yellow fever. I
thought at the time that he should have been court-martialed, and I
still think so.

(The following is confidential and is not to incriminate General
Kean. However, I am anxious to have it as a part of a meager evidence
that I think that Reed really was interested in the mosquito theory
before yellow fever.)

GENERAL KEAN: Reed told me of his conversation with General Sternberg;
my recollection is that he told me in the summer of 1902. I saw him
quite often that summer. He told me that he asked General Sternberg
before he went to Cuba whether he should pay any attention to the
study of the theory that the mosquito was a conveyor of yellow fever.
Sternberg said, “Well, you can do it if you want, but I think you will
be wasting your time”. Reed was very much irritated when he late heard
that General Sternberg claimed to have advise him to study the mosquito.
(See Mrs. Sternberg's Life of General Sternberg). Also this was
mentioned by Dr. Kober somewhere - possibly in his Autobiography.

So there a
autobiography

QUESTION #27 In the original Special Order AGO 122, May 24, 1900,
paragraph 34, photographs of which I have, and which I got from the
Archives Building, the statement is made “............for the purpose
of pursuing scientific investigations with reference to infectious
diseases, especially yellow fever, prevailing in the Island of Cuba”.
However, the order that appeared finally under date of the same day,
left out the words especially yellow fever, and in my photograph the
order is corrected in pencil to leave out these words. Somewhere I
was told that this may have been done for diplomatic reasons, not to
insult the Cubans, or at least not to emphasize to Americans who had
sons in Cuba they had yellow fever there. Have you ever heard any
explanation of why these words were left out?
ANSWER: I do not know any reason; I never heard it.

QUESTION #28: The original army photographs of Camp Lazear give the
impression that the camp was quite flat in all directions. As a
- 16 -
- 17 -
matter of fact my own photographs taken in the same direction as the
army photographs show the land relatively flat, but just a few hundred
yards in the opposite direction it is quite hilly, with little va.lleys
and hills. General Truby recollected that this was the condition at
Camp Lazear, that there were hills and valleys near by. What is your
recollection?

ANSWER: My recollection is that it was a rolling country right
near the camp.

QUESTION #29: Let me show you a photograph which Blossom Reed loaned
me three weeks ago. It shows her father on the boat on the way to
Cuba. She thinks it was taken on one of his first trips to Cuba on
his way to the yellow fever work. Why is he not in uniform?

ANSWER: We did not travel in uniform except with troops when
the country was not at war. In the first World War we had to wear
the uniform until the end of the war.

QUESTION #30: The one thing that puzzles me in General Truby's book
is his identification of the Surgery, or Walter Reed Laboratory figure
19 facing page 87, the same as figure 11 facing page 56. In figure
11 you can see on the right horizon a large building, which is un-
doubtedly General Lee's headquarters, Duranonia Building. If that
is so the picture was taken looking southeast. The 1902 map of
Camp Columbia would indicate Walter Reed Surgery facing west. In this
photograph it is facing north; in other words, its long axis seems to
have been changed. General Truby persists in his identification,
but admits the logic of my argument. However, he says that this
little building might very well have been moved or turned after the
- 17 -
- 18 -
rest of the Second Division Hospital and tents were removed, and when
this little building became part of the permanent wooden buildings of
the Columbia Base Hospital. It is difficult for me to see why they
would move a little building like this. Today we would not bother
to move such a building; we would build a new one as an easier way.
What is your recollection of this?

ANSWER: I think that the house is so nearly square that we cannot
be certain which is the long axis. Probably the building was not
moved at all; however it might very well have been moved. It would
have been no trouble to put a little house like that on rollers and
move it. “It was often done” (Kean)
